nodes.description: An unidentified suicide bomber detonated himself on a bus carrying Israel vacationers in the Bulgarian seaside resort on July 19, killing six people including Mustafa Kyosov.
nodes.support_text: An unidentified suicide bomber detonated himself on a bus carrying Israel vacationers in the Bulgarian seaside resort on July 19, killing six people including Mustafa Kyosov.

nodes.description: Jewish organizations offered financial help to the family of the non-Jewish Bulgarian bus driver killed in the terror attack.
nodes.support_text: Jewish organizations on Tuesday offered financial help to the family of a non-Jewish Bulgarian bus driver killed in a terror attack that targeted Israeli tourists in Burgas last month.

nodes.description: The Jewish Agency for Israel (JAFI) announced that Mustafa Kyosov's family would receive a $1,500 grant from the Fund for the Victims of Terror.
nodes.support_text: The Jewish Agency for Israel (JAFI) announced at a ceremony in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia that it will include the family of Mustafa Kyosov among recipients of aid from the Fund for the Victims of Terror.

nodes.description: Moshe Sharet, a JAFI emissary in Bulgaria, spoke at the ceremony in Sofia and said the grant was to ease the family's financial struggles and show solidarity with their loss.
nodes.support_text: Speaking at the central synagogue in Sofia, Moshe Sharet, a JAFI emissary in Bulgaria, said the $1,500 grant was given to Kyosovs to "ease their financial struggles and show the solidarity of the Jewish people with their loss."

nodes.description: Strategic Affairs Minister Moshe Ya'alon spoke at the ceremony, commenting on the victims and the nature of terrorism.
nodes.support_text: Strategic Affairs Minister Moshe Ya'alon also spoke at the ceremony on Tuesday, commenting that "dozens were injured simply because they were Jews and Israelis."

nodes.description: The terror victims fund created by the Jewish Federations of North America and operated by JAFI has given over NIS 100 million to families of victims and survivors of attacks in Israel and around the world.
nodes.support_text: The terror victims fund created by the Jewish Federations of North America and operated by JAFI has given over NIS 100 million to families of victims and survivors of attacks in Israel and around the world.

nodes.description: The grant given to the Kyosovs was made possible through a special donation by the Jewish United Fund/Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Chicago.
nodes.support_text: The grant given to the Kyosovs was made possible through a special donation by the Jewish United Fund/Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Chicago.

nodes.description: Terrorists attack innocent Jews and Israelis without distinguishing bloodlines or persons, and kill anyone who stands in their way.
nodes.support_text: Terrorism does not distinguish between blood and blood, and from person to person. Killers try to reach any place in the world to attack innocent Jews and Israelis, and would not hesitate to kill anyone who stood in their way when they implement their actions.

edges.support_text: An unidentified suicide bomber detonated himself on a bus carrying Israel vacationers in the Bulgarian seaside resort on July 19, killing six people including Mustafa Kyosov.
Jewish organizations on Tuesday offered financial help to the family of a non-Jewish Bulgarian bus driver killed in a terror attack that targeted Israeli tourists in Burgas last month.

The Jewish Agency for Israel (JAFI) announced at a ceremony in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia that it will include the family of Mustafa Kyosov among recipients of aid from the Fund for the Victims of Terror.

The Jewish Agency for Israel (JAFI) announced at a ceremony in the Bulgarian capital of Sofia that it will include the family of Mustafa Kyosov among recipients of aid from the Fund for the Victims of Terror.

Speaking at the central synagogue in Sofia, Moshe Sharet, a JAFI emissary in Bulgaria, said the $1,500 grant was given to Kyosovs to "ease their financial struggles and show the solidarity of the Jewish people with their loss."

The terror victims fund created by the Jewish Federations of North America and operated by JAFI has given over NIS 100 million to families of victims and survivors of attacks in Israel and around the world.
The event described in node_1 is an instance of the general terrorist attack described in node_8.
